data.title: /tmp cluttered with socket-files

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: openSUSE Tumbleweed (a roiling-release distribution, using Linux x64 4.11.6-1-default) 
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|haskero|Vans|1.3.1|
|hoogle-vscode|jcanero|0.0.4|
|language-haskell|justusadam|2.2.1|
|vscode-rust|kalitaalexey|0.4.0|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.62|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use VSCode, lately mostly for Rust, C & Haskell.
2. After some time the `/tmp` folder fills up with lots of vscode files.

`ls /tmp | grep vscode | wc -l`

Returns 62 items, IMHO way too much and clutters the `tmp` folder ‚Äì which I use occasionally when working with the terminal.

The file entries look like this:
```
vscode-8a833b0e-932f-4d6a-a66f-0b9068efa894.sock=
vscode-8b3da6d6-d075-4466-998a-1ebff8989c6e.sock=
vscode-95f2a0c6-39b5-4693-939e-62ee733f667d.sock=
```

Suggested solution
----------------------------

Create a sub-folder `/tmp/vscode` and use it for all temporary vscode files.

data.title: python interpreter uses incorrect encoding when invoked by a task
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 17.0.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|theme-chromodynamics|lei|1.0.8|
|ftp-sync|lukasz-wronski|0.3.3|
|MagicPython|magicstack|1.0.10|
|java|redhat|0.6.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.
Define the following task
```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "python3",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["${file}"],
    "showOutput": "always"
}
```
2.
Invoke it on the following python program

```
import sys

print(sys.stdout.encoding)
print('üêûüêû')
```

Output is something along the lines of:

```
US-ASCII
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/pvg/src/pyxample/soupy.py", line 4, in <module>
    print('\U0001f41e\U0001f41e')
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode characters in position 0-1: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Something similar happens in Windows as reported by an SO user here:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44724461/task-output-encoding-in-vscode

Curiously, invoking the above program with 'Run Python File in Terminal' does not have this problem, the program produces the expected output and completes. 

It is possible to work around the task problem by setting an environment variable although that it feels like that should not be necessary (the option itself is rather poorly documented).

```
{
    // See https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "python3",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["${file}"],
    "showOutput": "always",
    "options": {
            "env": {
                "PYTHONIOENCODING":"utf-8"
            }
    }
}
```

data.title: Intellisense Completion doesn't respect space after equal sign (.html file)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.4.2|
|prettier-vscode|esbenp|0.19.1|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.1.1|
|ftp-simple|humy2833|0.5.0|
|Theme-MaterialKit|ms-vscode|0.1.4|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.9|
|remote-vscode|rafaelmaiolla|1.0.1|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.4.0|
|Material-theme|zhuangtongfa|2.8.9|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.7.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  In a .html file, within a script tag
2.  Declare a variable, say `const abc = 5;`
3.  On another line, type `const def =`. Intellisense will pop up. Press the space key to place a space after the equal sign.
4.  Start typing `ab` to filter the list to the `abc` variable from the previous line. Press Enter or Tab to select that item.
5.  The space after the equal sign disappeared, and it now reads `const def =abc`. Ideally even if you didn't put a space after the equal, it should for you, but that's a stylistic issue.

Notes: I tried the same thing in a (.js) file and it did not happen.

data.title: Accessibility: MAS17: Color Contrast : Luminosity contrast ratio for the Iinks do not match 4.5:1 .
data.body:
Platform:
Microsoft Windows RS1
Version:10.0.14393.821
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2017 RC
Visual Studio/15.0.0-RC.4+26206.0

Steps to reproduce:
1. Launch Visual Studio Code.
2.Navigate to view menu.
3. Select "Extension" from view menu.
4. Select any of the extensions(example: select C# 1.8.1).
5.Observe the color contrast ratio for the links in the selected Extension tab using Contrast analyzer Application.

Expected Result:
Luminosity contrast ratio for the links should be 4.5:1.

Actual Result:
Luminosity contrast ratio for the links is 4.1:1.

User Impact:
People with low vision often have difficulty while reading the selected text that do not contrast with their background color.


![color contrast ratio for the links are minimum](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11685408/27495569-4560ebb2-5807-11e7-9104-0a06acff1230.png)

data.title: Accessibility: MAS17: Color Contrast : Luminosity contrast ratio for extension version text does not match 4.5:1
data.body:
Platform:
Microsoft Windows RS1
Version:10.0.14393.821
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2017 RC
Visual Studio/15.0.0-RC.4+26206.0

Steps to reproduce:
1. Launch Visual Studio Code.
2.Navigate to view menu.
3. Select "Extension" from view menu.
4. Observe the color contrast ratio for the Extension Version using contrast Analyzer.

Expected Result:
Luminosity contrast ratio for the text should be 4.5:1.

Actual Result:
Luminosity contrast ratio for the text is 4.3:1.

User Impact:
People with low vision often have difficulty while reading the selected text that do not contrast with their background color.



![color contrast ratio for the extension version is minimum](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11685408/27495506-fda89130-5806-11e7-9ae1-c9479e3e8cab.png)

data.title: Move line adds single space indent to import
[html][xml] Tab expansion creates tags even in attribute context
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0 - Extensions: (Note: tested with all disabled except "EditorConfig".) |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3| |quokka-vscode|WallabyJs|1.0.36| |vscode-svgviewer|cssho|1.4.2| |svg|jock|0.0.8| |vetur|octref|0.8.5| |twig|whatwedo|1.0.2|; --- Steps to Reproduce: From this HTML document: ```html 1.
2.
3.
4.
``` 1. Place the cursor after "div" in the first line, then type ` style` and hit the Tab key. 2. Place the cursor after "div" in the second line, then type ` test` and hit the Tab key. 3. Place the cursor after "style" in the third line, then hit the Tab key. 4. Place the cursor after "test" in the fourth line, then hit the Tab key. Expected result: ```html 1.
2.
3.
4.
``` Less expected but would-be-okay result: ```html 1.
2.
3.
4.
``` Actual result: ```html 1.
2.
>
3.
>
4.
>
``` I think the issue with the actual result is obvious. I would rather have the editor do nothing on Tab than creating tags in attribute context (and, as a user, having to remember not to use Tab at all in attribute context because it‚Äôs just too funky üòÄ ). Note: I looked at the list of issues tagged "html", and didn‚Äôt find an pre-existing issue. There are two issues with a broader scope (wanting the editor to be more context-and-vocabulary-aware and not simply syntax-aware), which might be duplicates of each other: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/375 https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19114 There is this feature request to auto-add double quotes after `attr=`: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/18071

data.title: Spacing in JSON causes collapse element to function incorrect.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:  (Disabled all)

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|swagger-viewer|Arjun|1.4.0|
|prettify-json|mohsen1|0.0.3|
|autorest|ms-vscode|0.12.3|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.4.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open up the swagger file located on [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/master/arm-storage/2015-06-15/swagger/storage.json).

2.  On line 240 you should see ""/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/providers/Microsoft.Storage/storageAccounts": {"

3. Click the [-] on line 240 to collapse.

4.  Does not collapse element correctly. (collapses remaining document)

5.  Modify spacing on line 240 so that the string matches the indentation on line 76

6. Click the [-] on line 240 to collapse.

7.  Collapses element correctly

data.title: Extension list in "Help > Report Issues" includes disabled extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0

Just a heads up: when using "Help > Report Issues", the extensions table include all extensions, even if they are disabled. This might be subpar for troubleshooting. It might be more useful to either include the enabled extensions only, or to include the loaded status.

Feel free to close this issue if that‚Äôs actually not a problem for you folks. :)

data.title: Error: "the path does not seem to exist anymore on disk" when the path does exist

|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.4.1|;



I have a bitlocker encrypted drive that I tried to open.  I have unlocked the drive and can access it from the File Explorer.  I've been able to access this in the past.  I restarted my computer and that's when this problem started happening.  After seeing the issue pop up, I restarted my computer again but I still see the issue.  

This is not a OneDrive folder - it's on a physical SSD on my machine.  I'm able to open folders on other drives, it's just the bitlocker one that I am unable to access. 

Things I've tried:
Restarting machine
Uninstalling/reinstalling VSCode (tried an older version as well, and that didn't seem to fix the issue)
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try to open a bitlocker encrypted drive that is unlocked.
2.

data.title: Move experiments logic into a separate service
data.body: Today the ITelemetryService contains the logic of experiments. Since that isn't really telemetry and since the telemetry service is implemented for different runtimes (standalone editor, ext-host, renderer) it should probably live in its own service.
